results.title: It’s Never Too Late to Climb That Mountain
results.abstract: Dierdre Wolownick, whose son, Alex Honnold, is one of the world’s top rock climbers, ascended Yosemite’s El Capitan to celebrate her 70th birthday.

multimedia.caption: In late September, Dierdre Wolownick climbed El Capitan in Yosemite National Park — again.

results.title: An Ice-Cream Parlor Where Time Stands Still
results.abstract: At Eddie’s Sweet Shop in Queens, the malts, shakes and sundaes are still made almost exactly as they were in the 1960s.

multimedia.caption: The Citrano family outside Eddie’s Sweet Shop in Forest Hills, Queens. From left: Vito Citrano, the current owner; his son Joseph; his father, Giuseppe; and Vito’s other son, Brandon.

results.title: Please Don’t Feed the Whale Sharks? Fishing Town Says It Must, to Prosper.
results.abstract: The chance to swim with the world’s biggest fish drew tourists to a Philippines town, but conservation groups denounce the hand-feeding that keeps the gentle creatures around.

results.title: A Future for People With Disabilities in Outer Space Takes Flight
results.abstract: People with different types of disabilities tested their skills and technologies on a zero-gravity research flight with the goal of proving that they can safely go to space.

multimedia.caption: Centra Mazyck, a passenger who is an incomplete paraplegic aboard AstroAccess Flight One, a parabolic flight that carried 12 people with physical disabilities to see how they would fare in a zero gravity environment.

results.title: United Airlines earned $473 million in the third quarter as travel demand stayed strong.
results.abstract: With government officials around the world slowly easing travel restrictions, and companies starting to send employees on more business trips, United’s executives expressed optimism about the coming months.

multimedia.caption: United expects to operate record numbers of flights to Europe, Latin America, India, Africa and the Middle East next summer.

results.title: In Sonoma County, ‘Regenerative Agriculture’ Is the Next Big Thing
results.abstract: Carbon sequestration, pollinator habitat restoration and simple composting:  An increasing number of the region’s winegrowers are going beyond sustainability. Here’s how to see, and taste, the fruits of their labors.

results.title: In Los Angeles, Glimpses of an Oasis With Deep Immigrant Roots
results.abstract: The San Pedro Community Gardens have provided physical and spiritual nourishment for the past half a century to multiple generations of immigrant Angelenos.

results.title: Whether Free, Affordable or Pricey, Testing Requirements Can Include a Headache
results.abstract: Coronavirus testing prices vary widely and can reach into the hundreds of dollars, making it hard for some travelers to budget for the added expense.

results.title: Traveling Alone, in Groups
results.abstract: Group tour companies are accommodating more and more solo travelers, who are looking for company — and someone else to handle the complexities of traveling during the pandemic.

results.title: House Hunting in the Seychelles: A Coral Island Paradise for $2.7 Million
results.abstract: Long a destination for tourists and high-end investors, the African archipelago is struggling to balance foreigners and locals in its housing market.

results.title: Walking an Adventure Playground
results.abstract: A new hiking path through Slovenia’s Julian Alps offers the pleasures of lakes and valleys rather than high peaks. It’s a worthwhile trade off.

results.title: The U.S. will reopen its land borders for fully vaccinated travelers.
results.abstract: Opening the borders with Mexico and Canada, where crossing for nonessential travel has been barred for 19 months, will reconnect neighbors and provide a reprieve for businesses.
results.byline: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Emily Cochrane

multimedia.caption: People cross the U.S.-Canadian border at Blaine, Wash., in August, after Canada opened its border to vaccinated Americans. The United States will open its land borders with Canada and Mexico to vaccinated travelers in November.

People cross the U.S.-Canadian border at Blaine, Wash., in August, after Canada opened its border to vaccinated Americans. The United States will open its land borders with Canada and Mexico to vaccinated travelers in November.

results.title: Iohan Gueorguiev, ‘Bike Wanderer’ of the Wilderness, Dies at 33
results.abstract: He gained a following online for his lyrical appreciation of the open road while biking through remote landscapes and braving extreme conditions.

multimedia.caption: Iohan Gueorguiev in 2020. Since 2014 he had been biking from the Arctic to Patagonia and chronicling his journey, often through extreme conditions, on his YouTube channel.

results.title: Agony and Ecstasy on the Scottish Archipelago of St. Kilda
results.abstract: The 85-mile boat ride through rough seas left some of us huddling in discomfort. But the scenery on the remote and windswept islands was otherworldly.

results.title: No Charges for Passenger Who Prompted La Guardia Emergency Landing
results.abstract: A spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said the authorities determined that there was “no criminality” involved in the landing.

results.title: Passing the Time With a Piano-Playing Pilot
results.abstract: As a pilot with United Airlines, Beau Brant flies North American routes. At every layover, he looks to play a mix of jazz, classical and more for his crew and strangers.

results.title: Back in Lesbian Paradise, at Long Last
results.abstract: The Dinah Shore Weekend, an annual festival for queer women, returned to Palm Springs last weekend after a two-year hiatus, this time with even more energy than usual.
